intro: Trachyspermum papillare, commonly known as mountain cumin, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic, compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant produces small, oval seeds that are used in traditional medicine and as a spice due to their pungent aroma. Trachyspermum papillare thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun, making it a suitable candidate for rock gardens and alpine settings. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for both horticultural study and culinary use.
